The dust of the flock was the first thing I knew of the world, and the last. It rose in a pale gold haze with the sun and settled, gritty on the tongue, with the moon. My father said it was the dust of our ancestors, the soil they’d worked and been buried in, now kicked up by the endless, stupid churning of the sheep’s hooves. I thought it was just dust. It smelled of lanolin and dry thyme and the faint, sharp tang of animal fear whenever a shadow passed too quickly overhead. It was the smell of my life, a map of my days written in scent. The hills that cupped our small valley were the edges of my world, their soft green shoulders humped against a sky so blue it ached to be looked at. Rome was a rumor to the south, a smudge of smoke and noise that I had no desire to visit. My world was here, in the bleating chorus, the solid weight of my crook, the sun-warmed stones I’d sit on to eat my bread and cheese.

It was a small world. And I was content in it. Or I thought I was. Contentment is a kind of sleep, and I had not yet been woken.

He came with the spring, when the Judas trees were bleeding their violent pink all over the hillsides. His name was Lucius. My father had arranged it, a decision so out of character that the earth might as well have tilted on its axis. ‘The boy stares too much,’ I heard him tell my mother through the thin wall of our hut. ‘He needs words for all that staring.’ My father was a man of hands, not words. He saw my quietness not as peace but as a deficiency, a vessel waiting to be filled. Lucius was to be the one to pour. He was from the city, a scholar my father had paid with three ewes and a promise of smoked meats for the winter. He was meant to teach me letters, numbers, how to read the missives and tax notices that came from the city, so we wouldn’t be cheated by the merchants.

He taught me so much more.

The first day, he sat with me on the hill, his tunic a startling, clean white against the dusty green of the grass. The sheep drifted around us, unconcerned. I was acutely aware of the dirt under my fingernails, the smell of wool that clung to my skin like a second self. He smelled of parchment and something clean, like soap made with olives. He was not much older than me, perhaps four or five years, but he carried himself with an old man’s stillness. His hair was the color of dark honey, and his eyes, when they met mine, were a startling grey, like the sky just before a storm.

“Hannelore,” he said, and my name, which had always sounded blunt and heavy, like a stone, felt different in his mouth. Smoother. “Your father tells me you wish to learn.”

I shrugged, picking at a loose thread on my worn tunic. “My father wishes it.”

A smile touched his lips, a small, knowing thing. “And what do you wish for, Hannelore?”

No one had ever asked me that. My wishes were simple, immediate things: for a straying lamb to return to the flock, for the rains to come at the right time, for the wolf to keep to its own territory. I had no answer for him. The silence stretched, filled only by the rhythmic cropping of the sheep. I felt my face grow hot.

He didn't press. Instead, he unrolled a small scroll of papyrus. The script on it was a forest of tiny, intricate black shapes. “This is a story,” he said, his voice soft. “About a man who travels to the end of the world and back. He fights monsters. He speaks to gods. He holds the entire sea in his palm.”

He began to read. The words were a language I did not know, but the sound of them, the cadence of his voice, was a kind of music. It rose and fell with the tale, now a whisper, now a resonant declaration that seemed to vibrate in the air around us. I watched his mouth as he formed the sounds. I watched the way his brow furrowed in concentration, the way his long fingers traced the lines of text as if he were touching the things he described. The sheep, the dust, the familiar hills—they all faded. There was only the sound of his voice and the vast, unseen world it was building in the air between us.

When he finished, he looked up, and the grey eyes were shining. “That was from the Odyssey. One day, you will read it for yourself.”

He started with the alphabet. He drew the letters in the dirt with a stick. ‘A,’ he said, drawing the sharp, angular shape. ‘Alpha.’ He made me trace it with my finger. His hand rested over mine, guiding it, and a shock went through me, a heat that had nothing to do with the sun. It was so light, his touch, but it felt like a brand. My world, which had been the size of this valley, suddenly had a new center, and it was the place where his skin met mine.

Days bled into weeks. The lessons became the anchor of my life. I would rush the flock to the high pastures, my heart a frantic drum against my ribs, eager for the time when he would arrive. He brought books filled with poetry, with philosophy, with histories of men who had conquered the world. He taught me of Plato, of the world of forms, the idea that the grubby, dusty world I knew was just a shadow of a perfect, truer reality.

“So,” I said one afternoon, lying on my back and staring at the clouds, “this sheep,” I pointed to an old ewe with a ragged ear, “is just a shadow? And somewhere else there is a perfect, ideal sheep?”

Lucius laughed, a sound like water over stones. He was lying beside me, propped on an elbow. “In a manner of speaking. Plato believed that the true form of ‘sheepness’ exists in a realm of ideas. All the sheep we see are just imperfect copies.”

“Does the perfect sheep have ragged ears?”

“No. It would have perfect ears. And perfect wool. And it would not smell quite so… pungent.”

I turned my head to look at him. A blade of grass was stuck in his honey-colored hair. Without thinking, I reached out and plucked it away. My fingers brushed his temple. He went very still. The laughter died in his eyes, replaced by something else, something deeper and more serious. The air thickened. I could hear my own breathing, loud and uneven. I did not pull my hand away. His skin was warm, soft. He leaned into my touch, just slightly, a movement so small I might have imagined it. His grey eyes searched mine, and in their depths I saw the same question that was clawing its way up my own throat.

That was the moment the lesson changed. He was no longer just my tutor. The words, the ideas, the histories—they were all just pathways leading to this. To the space between us, which was no longer empty but charged with a terrifying and beautiful energy. He was the truer reality Plato spoke of, and my whole life until he arrived had been nothing but a shadow. He had given me words for my staring, yes, but he had also given me a reason for it. I was not just looking at the world anymore; I was looking for him in it. In the curve of a hill that matched the curve of his shoulder, in the shade of an olive tree that was as cool and calm as his gaze, in the stubborn wildflower pushing through a crack in a rock, as beautiful and unexpected as his presence in my life.

The separation between teacher and student began to dissolve, like salt in water. The lessons grew longer, stretching into the dusk. We would talk of everything and nothing. He would ask about the sheep, the signs of the seasons, the language of the birds. He listened with a genuine fascination, as if my small, earth-bound knowledge was as wondrous as any story written on papyrus. I, in turn, drank in his words about Rome, about the Senate and the Forum, about the great marble buildings and the intricate, often brutal, politics of the city. He spoke of it with a strange mixture of pride and disdain. It was his home, the heart of the world, but it was also a place that had no room for a scholar who preferred poetry to profit, a man who saw more value in a shepherd's quiet wisdom than in a senator's loud proclamations.

One evening, as the sky turned the color of a deep bruise and the first stars pricked the darkness, he was reading to me from Sappho. His voice was low, and the words were about love, a desperate, aching love that felt impossibly familiar. He paused, his finger resting on a line.

“‘…and I am aware, in my heart…’” he read, then stopped. He looked at me, his face illuminated by the rising moon. “Do you understand what she means, Hannelore?”

I knew. I knew with a certainty that settled deep in my bones. The love she wrote of was not a gentle thing. It was a fire, a sickness, a madness. It was the frantic beat of my own heart when he was near.

“I think so,” I whispered, my voice hoarse.

He closed the book. “The things we read are not just ink on a page. They are pieces of other people’s souls. Sometimes, we find they match the pieces of our own.” He reached out, not with the accidental brush of a hand over mine, but with clear intent. He cupped my jaw, his thumb stroking the rough, sun-chafed skin of my cheek. “Your soul is not a simple one, shepherd. It’s as vast as these hills.”

He leaned in and kissed me.

It was not like the poets described. There were no fireworks, no clashing of cymbals. It was quiet, and slow, and it felt like coming home to a place I had never been. His lips were soft, hesitant at first, and they tasted of wine from the small flask he carried, and of himself, a taste I knew I would now spend the rest of my life craving. It was a kiss that unraveled me. The boy who was content with his flock, who knew only dust and sky, was gone. In his place was someone new, someone who had been touched by a scholar with storm-grey eyes, and who knew, with absolute, terrifying clarity, that he would never be whole without him again. My hand came up to rest on his chest, and I could feel the frantic, mirroring beat of his heart beneath my palm. It spoke the same language as my own. It was the only language that mattered. The world shrank to this single point of contact, this silent, breathless confession on a lonely hill under a canopy of indifferent stars. The flock was a soft, murmuring presence in the dark, the guardians of a secret that felt more sacred than anything the gods had ever devised. He had taken my small, simple world and cracked it open, revealing a universe inside.When we broke apart, the night air rushed into the space between us, cold and sharp. For a long moment, neither of us spoke. Lucius’s hand was still on my jaw, his thumb a point of warmth on my skin. In the pale wash of the moon, his storm-grey eyes were dark pools, and I could not read the weather in them. Panic, cold and swift, lanced through me. I had imagined it. I had ruined everything. He would leave, and the world would shrink back to its old, familiar dimensions, only now it would feel like a cage. I started to pull away, my face burning with a shame so hot it felt like a fever.

But he didn't let me go. His fingers tightened their gentle hold, keeping me there. "Hannelore," he breathed, and the name was a prayer, a question, an answer all at once. The fear receded, replaced by a wave of feeling so powerful it almost brought me to my knees. It was joy, but a wild, aching kind of joy that felt dangerously close to grief. He rested his forehead against mine, and I closed my eyes, breathing in the scent of him—parchment, and clean soap, and the faint, sweet trace of wine. We stayed like that, two heartbeats drumming a frantic, secret rhythm against the quiet hum of the sleeping world, until the moon climbed higher and cast our joined shadows long upon the grass.

Our lessons after that night were both the same and entirely changed. The structure remained—the alphabet, the sums, the reading—a necessary fiction for the benefit of my parents. But the substance of them had shifted. The space between us was no longer a student’s respectful distance, but a magnetic field, humming with unspoken things. When he corrected my clumsy attempts to form letters on the wax tablet, his hand would linger on mine. When we read from his books, our shoulders would press together, and I would be more aware of the heat of his body than of the words on the page. The poetry of Sappho and Catullus was no longer an academic exercise; it was our new language, a way of speaking about the fierce, tender thing that was growing between us without ever having to name it aloud.

Summer arrived in a blaze of heat, baking the hills to the color of old bread and making the air shimmer above the stones. The dust was a constant presence, a fine powder that coated everything, but I no longer minded it. It was the medium in which my life with Lucius was painted. We sought the shade of the gnarled olive groves for our lessons, the dappled light playing over his face as he read to me about the tragic loves of heroes and the musings of philosophers on the nature of the soul. He taught me that the Greeks believed some souls were split in two at the dawn of time, destined to spend their lives searching for their other half. Looking at him, at the way the light caught the gold in his dark honey hair, I felt the truth of that myth deep in my own bones. I had been wandering, incomplete, and I had not even known it until he arrived.

My father seemed pleased with the arrangement. ‘The boy can read the merchant’s bill now,’ he’d grunted to my mother one evening, his voice rough with pride. ‘He knows his numbers. The city man is earning his keep.’ I saw the relief in my father’s eyes. He believed the deficiency in me was being corrected, that the empty vessel was being filled with practical knowledge. He could not see that what Lucius was pouring into me was not practicality, but poetry; not numbers, but a dangerous and impossible love. He saw that my staring had not ceased, but he mistook its new intensity for scholarly concentration. He did not see that when I looked out at the valley, my gaze was always searching the path from our hut, waiting for the tell-tale flash of a clean white tunic against the green and brown of the world.

One sweltering afternoon, we abandoned the pretense of a lesson entirely. The sheep were drowsing in the thin shade of a carob tree, and the air was too thick and hot for letters. Lucius had taken off his sandals and was dangling his feet in the cool, slow-moving water of the stream that trickled down from the high pastures. I sat beside him on the mossy bank, watching the way the water swirled around his ankles. He was telling me about the aqueducts of Rome, marvels of engineering that carried fresh water for miles into the heart of the city, a concept so grand it was difficult for me to imagine.

“It is a city built on stolen water, just as it is an empire built on stolen lands,” he said, a familiar bitterness lacing his tone. He looked at me, a small, sad smile on his lips. “They can command rivers, but they do not know the peace of a simple stream like this one. They have libraries filled with more scrolls than you could read in a hundred lifetimes, but they have forgotten how to read the sky for rain.” He reached out and took my hand, lacing his fingers through mine. My hand was calloused and stained with dirt; his was smooth, the nails clean and perfectly shaped. The contrast was a map of our two different worlds, but in that moment, holding on to each other by the side of the stream, it felt like we were the only two people in an world of our own making.

“I would rather have this,” I said, my voice barely a whisper, gesturing to the stream, the hills, the sleeping flock. Then, more boldly, my eyes meeting his, I added, “I would rather have you.”

The sadness in his expression softened, replaced by that deep, serious look that made my heart stumble. “And I you, Hannelore.” He brought my rough hand to his lips and pressed a soft kiss to the knuckles. “More than all the libraries in Rome.” A shadow passed over his face then, a flicker of something I could not name. Fear, perhaps. Or sorrow. It was a look that acknowledged the fragility of our private world, the thinness of the walls we had built around it. The summer was already turning, the days growing imperceptibly shorter, and with the coming of autumn, the terms of my father’s agreement would be fulfilled. The promise of smoked meats for the winter was a clock, ticking down the time we had left. Lucius was a season in my life, as vivid and as fleeting as the Judas blossoms in spring, and the thought of his leaving was a cold stone in my gut.The shadow on his face did not pass. It lingered there for the rest of the afternoon, a subtle clouding of his features that I, who had learned to read his expressions as meticulously as I was learning to read his books, could not ignore. The promise of the coming winter, which had once been a distant and unremarkable certainty, now loomed like a headsman’s axe. Every sunset was a day stolen from us, every sliver of a waning moon a countdown. The easy rhythm of our summer afternoons was broken, replaced by a quiet, frantic urgency. Our conversations were still filled with poetry and philosophy, but underneath the words ran a current of unspoken grief. We were memorizing each other, hoarding small details—the way a lock of his hair fell across his brow, the precise curve of his smile, the scent of his skin in the late afternoon sun—like a starving man hoarding crumbs.

Autumn came not gently, but with a sudden, sharp wind that swept down from the northern hills, carrying the first real chill of the season. It stripped the last of the heat from the stones and sent the sheep huddling together for warmth. The dust, which had been a golden haze in the summer, now seemed grayer, colder. It settled on my clothes and in my hair with a new finality, a reminder of the life that was waiting to reclaim me. The vibrant world Lucius had shown me was beginning to feel like a dream I was slowly waking from, and the fear of finding myself back in the small, silent world of my past was a constant, bitter taste in my mouth. My father, oblivious, grew more cheerful as the days shortened. He pointed to the rows of smoked hams and sausages hanging in our storage hut. ‘Soon, scholar,’ he’d say to Lucius with a proud slap on the back. ‘Your payment is almost ready. You’ll eat well this winter in the city.’ Lucius would just smile, a tight, pale imitation of his real one, and the space between us would grow a little colder.

The letter arrived on a day when the sky was the color of slate, matching the grey of Lucius’s eyes. A courier on a sweat-streaked horse, wearing the insignia of a Roman house I did not recognize, stopped at our hut. He did not ask for my father, but for ‘the scholar, Lucius Vorenus.’ Lucius met him by the fence, his white tunic a stark slash against the brooding landscape. I watched from the hillside, my crook held in a white-knuckled grip, as he took the sealed scroll. I saw his shoulders tense as he read it, his posture losing its customary ease and becoming rigid, defensive. When he was done, he rolled the scroll slowly, methodically, his movements unnaturally precise. He did not look up at me on the hill. He turned and walked not towards the pastures, but in the opposite direction, his figure growing smaller and smaller until he disappeared over the rise.

He did not come for our lesson that day. I waited, the flock forgotten, as the sun dipped below the hills and the world bled into shades of grey and purple. A cold knot of dread tightened in my stomach. He had never missed a lesson. The silence he left behind was immense, a physical presence that pressed in on me. The bleating of the sheep sounded mournful, and the wind whispering through the dry grasses seemed to be speaking a single word: gone. I returned to the hut in the dark, my heart a leaden weight in my chest. I lied to my parents, mumbling that the scholar was unwell, a falsehood that felt like ash on my tongue. The world of perfect forms, of poetry, of other halves of a single soul—it all felt like a cruel fiction in the face of this raw, terrifying emptiness.

The next day he appeared at the usual time, but he was a stranger. The light in his eyes was shuttered, his face a mask of polite neutrality. He carried the wax tablet and stylus, as if this were any other day, any other lesson. He smelled of parchment and soap, but the warmth I associated with him, the energy that had always seemed to emanate from him, was gone. We sat on the cold ground, a chasm of silence between us. He drew a letter in the wax. ‘Delta,’ he said, his voice flat. I could not bear it. The pretense was a shard of glass in my throat.

“What did the letter say?” I asked, my own voice sounding harsh and accusing in the quiet.

He stopped, the stylus hovering over the wax. He would not meet my eyes. “It is a family matter, Hannelore. It does not concern you.”

The words struck me with the force of a physical blow. *It does not concern you.* I, who had become the center of his world, as he had become the center of mine, was now relegated to the periphery, an outsider. All the books, the shared secrets, the kiss in the moonlight—had they meant so little? Anger, hot and sharp, rose up to choke the grief. “You taught me to read,” I said, my voice shaking. “But you did not teach me how to read lies. Is that the next lesson?”

He finally looked at me then, and the anguish in his eyes was so profound it stole my breath. The mask was gone, and in its place was the man I knew, the man whose soul felt like the other half of my own. “They are calling me home,” he said, his voice cracking on the last word. “My father is ill. The estate is in disarray. I have been gone too long. I am the eldest son. I have… duties.”

Duty. The word was a stone wall, insurmountable. It was the language of fathers and sons, of Rome, of the world outside our valley. It was a language that had no translation for what we had become to each other. The anger drained out of me, leaving only a vast, cold emptiness. He was not choosing to leave; he was being taken. It was, in its way, even worse. There was no argument to be made, no plea that could change a thing. The axis of the world my father had thought tilted had righted itself, and it was throwing me off.

“When?” I whispered.

“Soon. As soon as your father declares my service complete.” He reached across the space between us, his hand covering mine where it rested, limp, on my knee. His touch was no longer a brand of thrilling heat, but a desperate, fleeting comfort against an encroaching winter. “Hannelore. Look at me.” I lifted my gaze to his. “This was not a lesson. This was not a summer pastime. Do you understand? This,” he gestured to the hills, to the space between us, to everything we had shared, “is the truest thing in my life.” His voice was thick with unshed tears. “And Plato was wrong. The perfect form is not in some other realm. It is here. It is this. It is a ragged-eared ewe, and the smell of thyme, and a shepherd who holds the whole sky in his eyes. And I have to leave it.”## 2.

We did not speak for a long time after that. The truth of his words settled over the hillside like a shroud. I have to leave it. A simple statement that dismantled the universe. He held my hand, his grip tight, as if he were trying to memorize the feel of my calluses, the map of veins on my skin. The wind grew colder, and I was aware of the sheep stirring restlessly nearby, their soft bleats the only sound in a world that had gone silent and airless. The lessons were a ruin, the future a wasteland. He had given me a world of infinite possibility and then told me its borders ended here, on this hill, with the turning of the season.

The last days were a singular, sustained agony. We kept up the pretense of our lessons, a hollow pantomime for the benefit of my father. Lucius would arrive, his face drawn and pale, and we would walk to the pastures. We no longer sat close enough for our shoulders to touch. The space between us now was not charged with unspoken desire but with the deafening silence of grief. We did not open the books. Their stories of gods and heroes felt like a mockery, tales of beings who could bend the world to their will while we, mere mortals, were being broken by it. Instead, we talked, or rather, I listened. He told me more of his life in Rome, not of the marble and the monuments, but of the gilded cage it was for him. He spoke of a betrothal, arranged years ago, to a woman he barely knew, a political alliance for his family. He spoke of his father, a stern, unyielding man who saw poetry as a weakness and scholarship as an indulgence. Lucius was not a free man returning to his home; he was a gilded possession being recalled by its owner.

“Take me with you,” I said one afternoon, the words tearing from me without thought. The sky was heavy with unshed rain, and the air was thick with the smell of damp earth. We were standing by the crumbling remains of an old shepherd’s shelter, a place we had often sought refuge from the sun. “I can work. I can be your servant. I can tend your gardens, your animals. Anything. Just… do not leave me here.”

Pain, sharp and pure, flashed across his face. He reached for me, his hands framing my face, his thumbs stroking my cheeks in that way that unmade me. “My sweet Hannelore,” he whispered, and his voice was so full of sorrow it felt like a physical weight. “You think Rome is like this valley, only bigger. It is not. It is a place of stone and iron rules. A shepherd boy, a… friend… from the provinces? They would not understand. They would not allow it. They would see you as a curiosity, a pet. Or worse. I could not protect you there. The very thing that is true and beautiful between us would be turned into something ugly, something they would use to destroy us both. Here,” he said, his gaze sweeping over the familiar, soft shoulders of the hills, “you are a king of this world. In Rome, they would make you nothing.”

I knew he was right. The world he had taught me about, the world of politics and power, had no place for a love like ours. My small knowledge of sheep and seasons was not currency there. I was a wildflower, and he was telling me I could not be transplanted into a formal Roman garden; I would simply wither and die. I leaned my forehead against his, and for the first time, I let the tears I had been holding back fall. They were hot against my cold skin. He held me, his own body trembling slightly, and we stood there as the first drops of rain began to spatter the dust around us, two halves of a soul mourning the world that would not let them be whole.

The day of his departure was unnaturally bright, the autumn sun sharp and clear in a sky that ached with its blueness. My father was in a boisterous mood, his voice booming as he presented Lucius with his payment: three plump ewes tied near the hut and a large bundle of smoked meats wrapped in burlap. “A fair trade!” my father declared, clapping Lucius on the shoulder. “You gave my boy words, and I give you a full belly for the winter! Rome will welcome you back a richer man!” Lucius smiled, that pale, fractured smile, and thanked him. My mother stood silently by the door of the hut, her arms crossed, her eyes on me. I wondered what she saw, what she knew. Her gaze was not unkind, but it was knowing, and in that moment, I felt a pang of love for her so sharp it was like a blade. She understood loss. She knew what a leaving looked like.

Our farewell was a stolen moment behind the storage hut, while my father was busy securing the ropes on the ewes. Lucius grabbed my hand, his fingers cold. He pressed a small, rolled scroll into my palm. It was the Sappho. “So you can read it for yourself,” he said, his voice thick. “When you read it, know that every word is mine, for you.” He looked at me, his grey eyes searching my face as if to burn the image of it into his memory. “Do not forget the world of forms, Hannelore. What we had… it is the truer reality. This parting is the shadow. Remember that.”

“I will not forget you,” I whispered, my throat so tight I could barely speak.

“Nor I you. Ever.” He leaned in, and for a fraction of a second, I thought he would kiss me, right there in the harsh light of day. But he only pressed his lips to my forehead, a brief, warm benediction. A promise. A goodbye. “Be well, shepherd,” he murmured against my skin, and then he was gone. I did not watch him walk down the path. I could not. I stood behind the hut, my fist clenched around the scroll, until the sound of my father’s cheerful farewells and the fading bleats of the three ewes died away.

I was left with the dust. It rose from the path where he had walked, a pale gold haze in the morning sun, and it settled on my tongue, gritty and tasteless. My world had not shrunk back to its former size. He had cracked it open, and now it was a vast and aching emptiness, stretching out in all directions. The hills that had once been the edges of my world were now just a barrier, a reminder of all the places I could not go, the life I could not have. I went back to the flock, the weight of my crook in my hand feeling alien and strange. The sheep churned the earth, kicking up the dust of ages. My father said it was the dust of our ancestors. Lucius had told me it was all just an imperfect copy of a truer world. I thought it was just dust. But now, it smelled of him. Of parchment and soap and a love that had bloomed and died in a single season. It was the smell of my life, a map of my days written in loss. Contentment is a kind of sleep, and I had been woken. And I knew, with a certainty that was as hollow and vast as the sky, that I would never truly sleep again.The days that followed his leaving were made of ash. I moved through the motions of my life, a ghost haunting the scenes of my own past. I led the flock to the high pastures, sat on the sun-warmed stones, and ate my bread and cheese, but the world had been leached of its color and savor. The sky was just a blank expanse, the hills were just mounds of dirt, the bleating of the sheep was a meaningless, irritating noise. My contentment had not just been a kind of sleep; it had been the very fabric of my existence, and Lucius had not woken me from it, he had set it on fire. Now I was left to walk through the scorched remains. My father, seeing my quietness return, mistook it for a settling, a return to normalcy. He thought the vessel was full and had now found its proper place on the shelf. He could not see the cracks spiderwebbing through me, the way I was slowly coming apart from the inside.

At night, in the close, smoky air of our hut, I would wait until my parents’ breathing deepened into sleep. Then, by the faint, flickering light of a tallow lamp, I would unroll the scroll. The elegant script that had once seemed a magical forest was now a dense, impenetrable thicket. I would trace the letters with a trembling finger, whispering their names into the darkness. *Alpha. Beta. Gamma.* They were the first gifts he had given me, the building blocks of his world, but without his voice to guide me, they were just shapes, as mute and unfeeling as stones. The frustration was a physical thing, a hot, tight ball in my chest. I was so close to him, holding the very words he had read to me, his voice a phantom echo in my memory, yet I was locked out. The scroll was a testament to both our connection and the vast distance that now separated us.

Winter fell upon the valley like a judgment. The winds howled down from the peaks, and the sky hung low and heavy, a lid on a pot of grey, cold stew. We were confined for long stretches to the hut and the barns, the world outside a blur of driven snow. The rhythm of my life became one of brute, simple survival: feeding the flock in their pens, mending fences, splitting wood until my hands were raw and my back ached. And in every spare moment, there was the scroll. It became my obsession, my private penance. I would stare at the lines of ink until my eyes burned, mouthing the sounds, trying to force the individual letters to surrender their solitude and join into words. My father saw me hunched over the papyrus and grunted in approval. ‘Good boy,’ he’d say. ‘Keep the letters fresh in your head. Don’t want the city man’s work to go to waste.’ He saw diligence; he did not see a drowning man clinging to a piece of wreckage.

My mother saw something else. She would watch me from across the small room, her hands busy with her mending, her expression unreadable. She never spoke of Lucius, not once. But one evening, as I struggled with a particularly difficult line, my shoulders knotted with frustration, she came and set a steaming mug of herbed goat’s milk beside me. Her hand rested on my shoulder for just a moment, a light, warm pressure that spoke more than words ever could. It was not a question or a judgment, but a simple, profound acknowledgment of my pain. In that silent touch, I felt a flicker of the warmth I had lost, and it was almost enough to break me. She knew. She did not know the specifics—the shared philosophies, the stolen kiss, the way my entire soul had been reordered—but she knew the shape of grief when she saw it.

The breakthrough came on a night so cold the timbers of the hut groaned in protest. I was tracing a line near the end of a stanza, a line I had heard Lucius read with such quiet intensity. ‘…*kai gignōskō, en emā kardíā*…’ My finger stopped. The sounds, which had been separate and awkward, suddenly clicked together in my mind, forming a bridge. *And I am aware, in my heart.* The words bloomed in the quiet room, as real as if he had just whispered them. It was not his voice I heard, but my own, yet it was his meaning, his feeling, that flooded through me. I kept going, piecing together the next phrase, then the next. A fire, a sickness, a sweet bitterness. It was all there. Sappho’s soul, laid bare on the page, was a mirror. The ink was no longer a barrier; it was a conduit, a direct line back to that evening on the hill when the world had cracked open. I bowed my head over the scroll, and a dry, ragged sob escaped my throat, the first sound of true feeling I had made in months.

From that night on, a change took root in me. The hollow ache of grief did not vanish, but it was joined by something else: a fierce, burning resolve. I was no longer just mourning a memory; I was actively communing with the part of him he had left behind. I devoured the Sappho scroll until I knew its verses by heart. Then I turned to the other scraps of writing I could find—the merchants’ bills my father had kept, an old tax notice, even the maker’s mark stamped on a clay pot. I read them all. I was gathering my tools, honing the weapons Lucius had given me. My quietness returned, but it was no longer the quiet of a boy with nothing to say. It was the quiet of a hunter watching, waiting. The quiet of a mind at work.

The rumor of Rome began to change in my thoughts. It was no longer a distant smudge of noise and smoke I had no desire to visit. Lucius had painted it as a cage, a place that would crush me, and I knew he was right. But it was also the only place in the world that held him. It was the heart of the empire he disdained, the home he had been recalled to, the location of his duty and his other life. The hills that cupped our valley, once my whole world, now felt like the walls of a prison. I would stand in the high pastures and stare south, past the familiar green shoulders of the land, trying to imagine the roads that led there. The thought was madness. I was a shepherd. My world was dust and lanolin and the turning of the seasons. But Lucius had told me that world was just a shadow. And he had said that our connection, what we were to each other, was the truer reality. And if that were true, then I could not remain in the shadow while he was in the world. The idea, once conceived, was impossible to dismiss. It grew in the silence of the winter nights, nurtured by the poetry of a long-dead woman and the memory of a scholar with storm-grey eyes. I would go to Rome. I did not know how. I did not know what I would do when I got there. I only knew that I could not stay here. I had been given a universe, and I would not allow it to be collapsed back into a single, lonely valley.## 3.

The spring returned, and with it, the violent, bleeding pink of the Judas trees. The color was a wound on the landscape, a raw anniversary of his arrival. A full year had passed. I was a different person, forged in the silent crucible of that winter. The grief had not lessened, but it had changed its nature. It was no longer a passive ache but an active force, a compass needle pointing south. The decision to leave was not a single, dramatic moment, but a slow, quiet crystallization of that single, driving need. I began to prepare in secret, a thief in the house I had known my entire life. I would set aside a portion of my bread at midday, letting it harden into a traveler’s rusk, hiding it in a hollow log in the pastures. From my father’s tools, I took a small, sharp knife. From the kitchen, a spare waterskin. I studied the merchants' bills not for the practice of reading, but for the names of the towns scrawled on them, trying to piece together a map of the world in my head. Each small act of pilfering was a stab of guilt, a betrayal of the small, simple world that had raised me, but the pull toward Rome was gravitational, undeniable.

I chose a night when the moon was a sliver of bone in a black sky. I could not face my father. His anger would have been a storm, but his disappointment would have been a weight I could not have carried. I packed my stolen supplies into a small sack, the Sappho scroll wrapped carefully in a piece of oilcloth at its heart. I moved through the hut like a shadow, my bare feet silent on the packed earth floor. But as I reached the door, a movement in the darkness stopped me. My mother was sitting up on her sleeping mat, a silhouette against the faint glow of the banked embers. She had been waiting. She did not ask where I was going, or why. She did not have to. She rose and came to me, her bare feet as silent as my own. In the near-total darkness, she pressed a small, heavy pouch of worn leather into my hand. I could feel the clink and heft of coins. It was not much, but for her, for us, it was a fortune. It was an act of impossible generosity, an investment in a hope she could not understand but whose desperation she recognized. She put her hands on my shoulders, leaned in, and kissed my forehead. Her lips were dry and warm. It was a blessing, a farewell, and an absolution all in one. I turned and slipped out the door without a word, my throat sealed with love and shame. I did not look back at the dark shape of the hut, or the soft, sleeping mass of the flock. I walked away from the only life I had ever known, into a world I could only imagine.

The reality of that world was an immediate and brutal shock. The road south was not a gentle track but a great, wounded artery, teeming with a desperate and hurried humanity I was utterly unprepared for. Carts pulled by straining oxen, legions of soldiers marching with a terrifying, rhythmic purpose, merchants with hard, calculating eyes, and worst of all, lines of slaves, their necks chained, their eyes vacant. I had never seen so many people, and I had never felt so alone. The dust of the road was acrid and choking, a compound of dirt, sweat, and animal filth that bore no resemblance to the clean, lanolin-scented dust of my valley. I learned in the first day to walk with my head down, my gaze fixed on the ruts before me, to make myself as small and unnoticeable as possible. I was a stray lamb in a world of wolves, and I knew it. The quietness that had been a deficiency in my father's eyes, and a canvas for Lucius’s words, now became my shield, my only defense against a world that was too loud, too fast, and too cruel.

The few coins my mother had given me vanished with frightening speed, traded for stale bread and the right to sleep in the corner of a noisy, flea-infested stable. Hunger soon became a constant, gnawing companion. I was a shepherd, skilled in the language of my own land, but this new terrain was hostile and foreign. I learned to look for wild onions and edible roots along the verges of the road, my knowledge of the earth a fragile inheritance in this tamed and brutalized landscape. One evening in a bustling market town, I tried to use the numbers Lucius had taught me to buy a handful of olives, only to be short-changed and laughed at by a merchant with a scarred face and merciless eyes. The shame of it was a hot flush that burned for hours. It was a harsh, practical lesson: knowledge was not just for poetry and philosophy; it was a weapon for survival, and I was still learning how to wield it. The soft boy who had debated Plato on a sun-drenched hill was being ground away by the grit of the road, and in his place, a harder, leaner, more watchful creature was taking shape.

As weeks bled into a month, the landscape began to change. The roads became wider, paved with great, dark stones that were unforgiving on my worn-out sandals. In the distance, I began to see the signs of immense wealth: grand villas with red-tiled roofs, set amidst carefully cultivated groves of cypress and olive, their walls so white they seemed to hurt the eyes. Then, one afternoon, I saw them. Striding across a wide valley on a series of impossibly tall arches was an aqueduct. It was just as Lucius had described it, a river in the sky, a monument to the staggering power and arrogance of Rome. It was a marvel of engineering, but seeing it, I felt not awe but a cold knot of resentment. This was the world that owned him. This was the structure built on stolen water, part of the empire built on stolen lands, a symbol of the very power that held him in its gilded cage, away from me. The anticipation that had been a dull ache in my chest for weeks now sharpened into a painful, frantic beat, a mixture of profound hope and an even more profound terror.

I crested a final hill at dusk, my body screaming with exhaustion, my spirit frayed to a single, stubborn thread. And then I saw it. It was not a city. It was a wound in the earth, a sprawling, incandescent lesion of light and shadow that filled the entire basin before me and clawed its way up the seven hills. The rumor of Rome was a pathetic whisper compared to this reality. The noise was a physical presence, a low, constant roar that vibrated in my bones—the sound of a million lives, a million desires and despairs, all ground together. The scale of it was an obscenity. It could swallow my valley, my hills, my entire world, and not even register the meal. For a long moment, I could not breathe. I was a single grain of dust facing a hurricane. Every step of my journey, every hardship, had led me here, to the edge of this beautiful, terrible monster. How could one person ever hope to find another in that seething chaos? The journey from my valley was over. I had arrived. But standing there, gazing down at the heart of the world, I understood that my true, and perhaps impossible, search had only just begun.3.

I stood on that hill until the last of the light had been devoured, and the sprawling beast below became a galaxy of flickering, earth-bound stars. The cold night air began to creep into my thin tunic, a physical manifestation of the chill that had seized my soul. The journey had been a line, a single direction, but here, at its end, the path fractured into a million possibilities, a million dead ends. Taking a breath that felt like swallowing shards of glass, I started down the slope, my footsteps clumsy in the dark, my descent a surrender to the monster’s gravity. The roar grew louder as I approached, resolving itself into individual sounds: the rumble of iron-shod wheels on stone, the distant shouts of a thousand arguments and bargains, the braying of a mule, the thin, high wail of a child. Then the smell hit me, a suffocating wall of scent. It was the smell of too many people living too closely together—of sewage and woodsmoke, of frying fish and stale wine, of sweat and perfume and sickness and death, all layered one on top of the other until the air itself felt thick and greasy. My valley smelled of life, too—of lanolin and thyme and wet earth. This city smelled of life being consumed.

That first night, I found no stable, no corner of charity. I crept into a narrow, refuse-strewn alley between two towering, crumbling tenement blocks that seemed to lean into each other, blotting out the sky. I huddled in a doorway, pulling my knees to my chest, my small sack clutched as if it were a shield. Every footstep in the main street sent a jolt of terror through me; every burst of drunken laughter felt like a threat. The city was a predator, and I was soft, field-raised meat. I closed my eyes and tried to summon the image of Lucius’s face, the memory of his hand on mine, but the city’s grinding, relentless noise made it difficult. The truer reality felt very far away, a half-forgotten dream. The shadow world was here, and it had teeth. I spent the night in a state of shivering, wakeful dread, the cold, unforgiving stone of Rome leeching the warmth from my bones.

Dawn did not break so much as it seeped into the city, a weak, grey light that revealed the full extent of the filth and squalor around me. The city stirred itself to life, and I was swept up in its current. The primary, brutal fact of my existence was no longer love, but hunger. It was a hollow, aching void in my belly that overrode every other thought. I watched the city’s laborers begin their day: broad-shouldered men with impassive faces, hauling sacks from wagons, carrying water yokes, their bodies machines built for toil. I saw my future in them. The boy who read Sappho was a luxury I could not afford. The boy who could carry a lost ewe for miles across rugged hills, however, might just earn enough for a piece of bread. I had to become a body, a pair of hands, an anonymous cog in this vast, indifferent machine. The search for Lucius would have to wait. First, I had to survive Rome.

My first work was at the river port, unloading clay amphorae filled with Spanish olive oil from a wide, flat-bottomed barge. The foreman, a man with a belly like a wine sack and a voice like grinding stones, looked me over with contempt, then pointed to a line of other desperate-looking men. The work was mind-numbing and back-breaking. I would hoist a heavy, two-handled jar onto my shoulder, my muscles screaming in protest, and carry it up a slippery gangplank and into a cavernous, foul-smelling warehouse. I dropped the first one. It shattered on the stones, the precious oil spreading in a golden, fragrant pool. The foreman backhanded me across the face so hard my ears rang, the blow a stark pronouncement of my new station in life. I did not drop another. By the end of the day, my tunic was soaked with sweat, my shoulder was a raw, bruised mess, and my hands were blistered, but in my palm, I held two small copper coins. They felt heavier than any stone I had ever lifted, each one a universe of pain and humiliation away from the pouch my mother had given me.

With those coins, I found a new life, if such a thing could be called living. I bought a wedge of hard, gritty bread and a handful of wilted greens from a street vendor. Then I followed the other laborers into the labyrinthine alleys of the Subura, the city’s teeming, chaotic gut. For a portion of my second day's earnings, I secured a space on the floor of a cramped, windowless room in a towering *insula*, shared with five other men who smelled of sweat, cheap wine, and despair. We slept in shifts. The air was thick with snoring and coughing, the thin walls offering no barrier to the constant shouts and arguments of our neighbors. This became my world: the brutal, repetitive labor at the docks by day, and the noisy, suffocating darkness of the tenement by night. The shepherd boy was buried under layers of city grime and exhaustion. My hands, once calloused from the familiar wood of my crook, were now calloused from the unfamiliar clay of Roman jars. I was becoming part of the shadow, my own outlines blurring into the city’s great, dirty mass.

But I did not let the fire go out. In the evenings, when every muscle screamed for rest, I would force myself back out into the streets. The exhaustion was a kind of shield, my dirt-stained clothes and weary face a perfect camouflage. I was invisible, and I used that invisibility. I began to learn the city, not its grand avenues, but its veins and capillaries. I learned which public fountains had the cleanest water, which bakers’ ovens vented the most heat into the alleys for a moment’s warmth. And I began my search. I could not simply ask for a great scholar. That would invite suspicion, or worse, mockery. So I invented a story. I was a messenger, I would say to a clerk at a public records office, or a scribe in a small market stall. I carried a message for the house of Vorenus. The name felt strange and precious on my tongue, a secret jewel I was forced to display to strangers.

The responses were always a variation on a theme of dismissal. A shrug. A shake of the head. “Vorenus is a common name, boy. Which branch?” a harried official would snap, not waiting for an answer. At the grander houses on the Esquiline Hill, where I dared to approach the gates, I was chased off by guards with contemptuous sneers. “The Vorenus family? They have no business with filth like you. Be off before I set the dogs on you.” Each rejection was a small death, a confirmation of Lucius’s warning. The city had no place for me, and it was intent on reminding me of that fact at every turn. Some nights, crushed by the futility of it all, I would return to my corner of the floor and unroll the Sappho scroll. The papyrus was becoming soft and frayed from handling, the ink faded in places. Tracing the letters he had taught me, whispering the words that had passed between us, was the only thing that held the despair at bay. It was my anchor to the truer reality, a reminder that the boy on the hill had been real, that the man with storm-grey eyes was not a figment of my imagination.

The clue came, as such things often do, not from searching, but from listening. I was in a grimy wine bar near the Forum Boarium, a place where dockworkers and minor clerks drank to forget the day. I was nursing a cup of watered-down wine, making it last, when I overheard the conversation from the table next to me. Two men, their tunics of better quality than mine, were complaining about their work. “The whole estate is a mess since old Gaius Vorenus died,” one said, swirling his wine. “The will is being contested by his brother, and the son is impossible.” My entire body went rigid. I did not dare to look at them, but I strained to hear over the din of the tavern. “Which son?” the other asked. “The soldier?” “No, the scholar,” the first replied with a snort of derision. “The one they dragged back from the countryside somewhere. Spends all day with his books and refuses to sign anything. Thinks poetry is more important than property lines. He’s driving the magistrates mad.” The world, which had been a chaotic blur of noise and misery, suddenly snapped into sharp, brilliant focus. Gaius Vorenus. A dead father. A contested will. A scholar son. It was him. The man’s next words were a gift from the gods. “If he doesn’t show up at the Praetor’s court tomorrow to answer the petition, he’ll forfeit the entire Palatine villa.” He had given me a time, and a place. The Praetor's court. Tomorrow. My heart, which I had thought was turning to stone, began to beat with a wild, frantic hope that was so painful it felt like my ribs might break.## 4.

Sleep was an impossibility. The hope churning in my gut was a physical sickness, a wild, manic energy that had my nerves stretched as taut as a bowstring. Long before the first grey light polluted the alleyways, I was awake, my heart hammering a frantic rhythm against the dirty floorboards. The tavern talk echoed in my mind: *The Praetor’s court. Tomorrow.* The words were a spell, a key, a destination. After months of aimless, soul-crushing wandering, I had a direction. I crept out of the tenement while my roommates snored their drunken, oblivious chorus, and made my way to the nearest public fountain. The water was icy, and I scrubbed at my face and hands with a desperate ferocity, trying to wash away the accumulated grime of the docks, to somehow excavate the shepherd boy from beneath the laborer’s filth. I saw my reflection in a still puddle: a gaunt, hollow-cheeked stranger with wild eyes and hair matted with sweat and dirt. My tunic was stiff with grime and stained with oil. Would he even know me? Or would he see just another piece of city refuse and turn away in disgust? The thought was a spear of ice in my chest. I used the last of my coppers not on bread, but on a small, rusted razor from a street vendor, and in the shadow of a temple wall, I scraped away the rough stubble on my chin, nicking myself a dozen times. It was a pathetic, futile gesture, but it was all I could do. I was trying to make myself worthy of a memory.

The Roman Forum was not a place one simply walked into; it was a place that assaulted the senses and humbled the soul. As I passed under the Arch of Tiberius, the noise and squalor of the Subura fell away, replaced by a different kind of chaos: the orderly, overwhelming clamor of power. The sheer scale of it was dizzying. White marble temples with gilded roofs clawed at the sky, their columns as thick as ancient trees. Statues of gods and emperors stared down with cold, stone eyes, their expressions of serene authority a stark rebuke to my own frantic anxiety. The air was filled with the resonant boom of orators declaiming from the Rostra, the drone of advocates arguing in the basilicas, and the constant, purposeful scuff of thousands of leather sandals on stone. Men in crisp, white togas, their faces masks of serious self-importance, strode through the crowds with their entourages of clerks and slaves, parting the lesser humanity like ships parting water. I had never felt smaller, more insignificant. I was a speck of dust in the heart of a marble quarry, and my worn tunic and scarred hands were a declaration of my foreignness, my utter lack of belonging.

I found the building designated as the Praetor’s court, a massive, colonnaded basilica teeming with activity. There was no hope of getting inside. Legionaries stood guard at the main entrances, their armor gleaming, their expressions bored and dangerous. They were a human wall separating the world of consequence from the world of rabble, and I was firmly on the wrong side. So I waited. I found a spot at the base of a towering column, trying to make myself look as inconspicuous as possible, my gaze fixed on the court’s entrance. The sun climbed, beating down on the white stone until the glare was blinding. My hunger, forgotten in the morning’s frantic preparations, returned with a vengeance, a dull, insistent ache in my stomach. The crowds swelled and shifted. Litters carried wealthy matrons through the throng, their curtains drawn against the gaze of the common folk. Senators debated in low, urgent tones, their gestures sharp and precise. Every man who emerged from the court with dark honey-colored hair sent a jolt through my system, a false alarm that left me trembling and breathless. Time stretched and warped. Minutes felt like hours. I began to fear I had missed him, that the tavern gossip was wrong, that this whole desperate venture was just another cruel joke played by the gods. The hope that had burned so brightly began to gutter, threatening to be extinguished by the cold wind of futility.

And then I saw him. He emerged from the shadows of the portico into the bright, unforgiving sunlight, and the world stopped. It was Lucius, but it was not. The man who stepped into the Forum was a stranger wearing a familiar face. He was not dressed in the simple, clean tunic I remembered, but in the heavy, formal folds of a dark woolen toga, the garb of a Roman citizen in mourning and on official business. It was a costume that seemed to wear him, constraining his natural ease, making his movements stiff and unfamiliar. His hair was shorter, combed back from his brow with a severe precision. His face was thinner, paler, and carved with lines of exhaustion and worry that had not been there in the valley. The scholar’s stillness I had loved was gone, replaced by a tense, restless energy. He was flanked by two older men, their faces pinched and severe—his uncle, perhaps, and a lawyer—who spoke to him in low, insistent tones. Lucius did not seem to be listening. His gaze was distant, his storm-grey eyes clouded over, fixed on some point far beyond the Forum’s marble splendor. He looked trapped, a beautiful, intelligent animal caught in a snare, and the sight of it broke my heart anew.

He was twenty paces from me. My body moved before my mind could form a coherent thought. I pushed off from the column, stumbling into the flow of the crowd, my whole being focused on that single, impossible point. “Lucius!” The name was a ragged tear in the fabric of the Forum’s noise. It was too weak, swallowed by the din. I shoved past a corpulent merchant, earning a curse. I was getting closer. He had stopped, his head turned as if listening for something, his brow furrowed in a flicker of the old concentration I knew so well. I could see the fine hairs on the back of his neck, the familiar curve of his ear. I filled my lungs, a desperate surge of adrenaline coursing through me. “Lucius!” I shouted again, louder this time, my voice raw with a year of silence and a thousand miles of road. This time, he heard me. His head snapped around. His eyes, those grey eyes that held my entire world, widened as they scanned the crowd, searching. And then they found me.

For one infinite, suspended moment, our gazes locked across the sea of strangers. The noise of the Forum, the heat of the sun, the ache in my belly—it all vanished. There was only the shock of recognition on his face, a look of such profound, incredulous disbelief that it was like a physical blow. He saw me. He knew me. His lips parted, my name forming on them, silent and unseen. But the moment shattered. One of his companions, the severe-faced uncle, saw the direction of his gaze. His eyes narrowed with disdain as he took in my filthy tunic, my wild, desperate appearance. He placed a firm, proprietary hand on Lucius’s arm. “Come,” he said, his voice sharp with command, “We are late.” He tugged Lucius, breaking the fragile thread of our connection, turning him away. Lucius stumbled, looking back over his shoulder, his face a mask of conflict and anguish. I saw him shake his head, a minute, desperate gesture. *Don’t,* it seemed to say. *Not here. Not like this.* Then he was swallowed by his entourage, a prisoner being led away by his keepers, and swept into the river of bodies flowing down the Sacra Via. I was left standing alone, the wake of their passage closing around me, the spot where he had stood now occupied by a senator’s aide complaining about the heat. He had seen me. And he had left. The hope that had carried me across the empire collapsed into a cold, dense star of despair in my chest. I had found him, only to lose him all over again, and this time felt infinitely more final.For a long moment I did not move, a statue of dirt and rags amidst the flowing river of togas and tunics. The space where he had stood was a hole in the world, a vacuum that sucked all the air from my lungs. I was an island, and the tide of the Forum was parting around me, the faces that passed a blur of indifference and mild irritation at my presence. Then a legionary, seeing me rooted to the spot, gave me a hard shove in the back. “Move along, filth,” he grunted, the words a casual cruelty. The shove broke the spell. I stumbled forward, my legs unsteady, and my body took over, carrying me away without any conscious direction from my mind. I fled, not with the frantic energy of my arrival, but with the shambling, defeated gait of a broken animal. I fled the blinding white marble that seemed to mock my grief, the booming voices of power that declared my insignificance, the cold stone eyes of the emperors who had built this world that had swallowed my own.

I found my way back to the Subura, the maze of teeming, narrow streets a perverse comfort after the Forum’s terrifying openness. The familiar stench of charcoal smoke and sewage was the smell of my new reality, and I sank into it like a dying man sinking into a fever bed. I did not go back to the tenement room; I could not face the empty cheer of the other laborers, their small talk about wine and dice. I found my first home in the city, the refuse-strewn alley, and collapsed in the same doorway where I had spent my first night. The hunger was a distant, unimportant signal. The bruises from the docks were nothing. All feeling had been concentrated into a single, dense point of pain behind my ribs. I curled into a ball, my forehead pressed against my knees, and let the scene in the Forum play over and over in my mind, a form of self-torture. Lucius in a toga. Lucius looking trapped. His uncle’s hand on his arm, a manacle of flesh and bone. The brief, desperate, agonizing connection of our eyes. And his retreat.

But as the hours passed and the shadows in the alley lengthened, the sharp edges of despair began to dull, worn down by the sheer force of my will to understand. I forced myself to dissect the moment, to be the scholar he had tried to make me. I had to read the signs, not just feel the blow. He had not turned away from me in disgust. The shock on his face was not revulsion; it was pure, unadulterated terror. The way his lips had formed my name, the slight, desperate shake of his head before he was pulled away—it was not a dismissal. It was a warning. *Not here. Not like this.* Lucius’s warning from the valley echoed in my mind with chilling clarity: *I could not protect you here.* He had not been rejecting me; he had been trying to save me from the very thing that was now crushing him—the brutal, iron rules of his world. He was a prisoner, and I had just stormed the walls of his prison and shouted his name, foolishly announcing myself to his jailers.

A new emotion began to smolder beneath the ash of my despair: anger. It was a cold, quiet fury, directed not at Lucius, but at the world that held him. At the sneering uncle, at the oppressive weight of the toga, at the entire magnificent, monstrous city and the obligations it demanded. Lucius had told me that our connection was the truer reality and that our parting was the shadow. I had clung to that idea like a prayer. Now, I saw it was not just a comforting philosophy; it was a battle plan. The Forum, the villa, the stern-faced relatives—that was the shadow world. It was a powerful, dangerous illusion, but an illusion nonetheless. And I would not let it win. The boy who had cried on the hillside was gone, burned away by the journey south. The laborer who had hauled amphorae until his shoulders bled was just a disguise. The real me, the person Lucius had unearthed, was still there, and he was not going to run back to the valley with his tail between his legs.

I sat up, the alley’s gloom no longer a shroud but a conspirator’s cloak. My objective had been too simple, too naive. Find Lucius. I had found him. Now the real work began. I had to reach him. The direct approach was impossible; the legionary’s shove had proven that. I could not approach his world as Hannelore the shepherd. That boy was a vulnerability, a weakness his enemies would exploit to hurt him. I had to find another way, a hidden path. The words from the tavern came back to me, no longer a simple clue, but a strategic map: *The Palatine villa.* That was his prison. A prison needs servants. It needs laborers, gardeners, kitchen boys, stable hands. It needs an endless supply of the city’s invisible people, the human dust that settles in the corners of the great houses, seeing all and noticed by none. I would stop being a person and become a function. I would use the grime of the city that I had despised as camouflage. I would learn the secret language of the back doors and the servant’s quarters. I would not find my way to him through poetry, but through ashes and kitchen scraps. I would become a shadow to slip into his shadow world. And I would find him again.## 5.

The alley ceased to be a tomb and became a war room. The anger that had replaced my despair was a cold, clean flame, burning away the last of the boy who had wept on the hill. My new plan was not one of passion but of stealth, a strategy born from the harsh lessons Rome had taught me. I was not a poet’s lover storming the gates; I was a parasite seeking a way into the body of the host. I did not return to the river. The brute labor of the docks offered strength but no subtlety, and subtlety was the only weapon I now possessed. Instead, I began to haunt the fringes of the great markets, the Emporium and the Forum Boarium, where the lifeblood of the city’s elite was bought and sold. I was no longer looking for work to fill my belly, but for a vector, a path that led to the Palatine Hill. I watched the delivery wagons, noting the insignias painted on their sides. I listened to the gossip of the teamsters and the clerks, learning which merchants supplied which great houses, my mind a ledger of connections and possibilities.

The opportunity, when it came, was draped in black. The tavern gossip had mentioned the death of Lucius’s father, and now the consequences of that death rippled down into the city’s economy. The House of Vorenus was preparing for the *cena novendialis*, the great funeral feast held nine days after the burial. It was to be a massive affair, a public display of grief and, more importantly, of continued status. Such an event required a near-military mobilization of resources, and the household staff, no matter how large, would be overwhelmed. Word spread through the markets like wildfire: the Vorenus villa was hiring temporary help. Scullions, servers, runners, extra hands for the kitchens—anyone with a strong back and a tolerance for being shouted at. It was an open door, a chink in the armor of the great house, and I ran toward it.

I presented myself at the service entrance of the villa, a formidable iron-studded gate set into a high stone wall, a world away from the grand, columned entrance Lucius must have used. I was one of perhaps fifty desperate souls, a motley collection of the city’s hopeful and hungry, all vying for a few days of work. We were inspected by a sour-faced majordomo, a freedman whose curled hair was greasy with pomade and whose eyes missed nothing. He walked down the line, his gaze lingering on a man’s weak chin or a woman’s dirty hands before dismissing them with a flick of his fingers. He stopped in front of me. I did not meet his eye. I stood straight, my hands loose at my sides, affecting an air of dull, placid obedience. I had learned that much. Thinking was a liability; a blank face was an asset. He grunted, prodded my shoulder with a hard finger as if testing a cut of meat, and then gestured me through the gate along with a dozen others. I did not allow my face to show the wild, triumphant leap of my heart. I had breached the first wall.

The world inside that gate was another city in miniature, a frantic, hierarchical ecosystem dedicated entirely to the comfort of the few who lived in the grand house beyond. The air was thick with the smoke from the bakehouse and the reek from the latrines. Slaves hurried back and forth on mysterious errands, their expressions carefully blank. I was herded with the other new hires into the kitchens, a vast, cavernous space that was already a vision of hell. The heat from a dozen open hearths and brick ovens was a physical blow, and the noise was a deafening symphony of clanging pots, chopping knives, and the bellowed commands of the head cook. He was a mountain of a man with a scarred face and the thick arms of a blacksmith, a Gaul named Brennus who ruled his domain with a ladle handle and a vocabulary of creative curses. He took one look at our sorry group and pointed me and two other men to a dark, wet corner. Our job was the lowest in this underworld: we were scullions. We were to wash the endless tide of greasy pots, scrub the blood and offal from the stone floors, and keep the fires fed, all without speaking unless spoken to. We were not even given names. We were simply "boy," "you," or a gesture. I was invisible. It was perfect.

My life became a cycle of sweat and servitude, measured not in days but in mountains of soiled cookware. From before dawn until well after the main house had gone to sleep, I worked until my arms were lead and my back was a single, continuous ache. I slept on a straw pallet in a cramped, windowless room with twenty other male servants, a place that reeked of unwashed bodies and sour wine. The gnawing hunger of the road was replaced by the constant, cloying smell of food I was not allowed to eat. Yet, I felt no despair. The pain was purposeful. The exhaustion was a shield. The simmering anger in my heart was the fuel that kept me moving. And all the while, I listened. The kitchen was the nerve center of the house’s gossip, the place where secrets from upstairs were dissected, embellished, and traded like currency. I learned that Lucius’s uncle, Lucius Quintus, was now the acting head of the family and was pressing Lucius to marry his betrothed, a high-born girl named Cornelia, immediately, to secure the family’s alliances. I learned that Lucius rarely left his library, that he refused his uncle’s commands, and that the tension in the villa was as thick as the smoke from our fires. I had not seen him, not once. He was a ghost in his own home, a name whispered among the staff. I was a ghost in his kitchen. We were separated by a few hundred feet of stone and a gulf as wide as the empire, but I was closer than I had been in a year, and I would wait. I had learned the patience of the hunter, and I would scour every pot in Rome if it meant one day finding a way back to him.The days leading up to the *cena novendialis* were a descent into a deeper circle of hell. The kitchen, already a frantic space, became a vortex of controlled pandemonium. Carts arrived laden with whole pigs, cages of squawking fowl, and amphorae of rare Garum from Spain. The air grew thick with the smells of roasting meat, exotic spices I couldn't name, and the ever-present undertone of simmering panic. Brennus, the head cook, was a terrifying force of nature, his voice a constant roar, his ladle a weapon that fell indiscriminately on the backs of lazy slaves and clumsy hires alike. I kept my head down, my movements swift and efficient. I learned to anticipate the need for more firewood, to have a clean pot ready before it was demanded, to scrub a blood-stained butcher’s block with a silent, furious energy that seemed to satisfy him. My invisibility was my armor. While others were cursed and dismissed, I was simply overlooked, a functional part of the machinery, and in that anonymity, I found my power.

The gossip intensified with the workload, becoming sharper, more detailed. The servants spoke of the master, Lucius Quintus, and his growing fury at his nephew’s intransigence. They whispered about Cornelia, the intended bride, a phantom of beauty and wealth who had been seen weeping in the gardens. But it was the talk of Lucius that I strained to catch, filtering it from the noise like a gold panner sifting through silt. I learned his library was in the west wing, overlooking the "quiet" garden, a secluded space walled off from the rest of the grounds. I learned he took his meals there, simple trays of bread, cheese, and wine, refusing the elaborate dishes prepared for the rest of the household. The servants who delivered these trays were cursed with the task, as Lucius either ignored them completely or looked at them with a disconcerting intensity, as if searching their faces for something that wasn't there. Each detail was a piece of a map I was constructing in my mind, a map that led from this greasy, steaming underworld to a quiet room in the west wing.

The day of the feast arrived. The villa was transformed, the air humming with the nervous energy of performance. Upstairs, beyond my ken, the sounds were muted and solemn—the scrape of formal chairs, the low murmur of mourners. Downstairs, it was a battle. Hundreds of dishes had to be prepared and sent up in precise waves. Brennus was a general on the verge of routing, his face purple, his voice hoarse from shouting. I worked in a blur of motion, my arms submerged to the elbows in greasy water, my skin slick with sweat and steam. It seemed impossible that any opportunity would arise from this chaos. I was chained to my washing trough, a fixture as permanent as the stone floor. Then, it happened. A young slave boy, tasked with carrying a tray upstairs, slipped on a patch of spilled oil, sending a silver platter of honeyed dates crashing to the floor. Brennus’s rage was biblical. He seized the boy by the ear, his roar echoing off the stone walls, and threw him out into the yard. A replacement tray was prepared in seconds, but there was a moment of hesitation. Every available server was already deployed. Brennus’s furious gaze swept the kitchen, and for the first time, it landed on me. He saw not a person, but a pair of clean—or at least, recently washed—hands. “You,” he barked, pointing with a greasy finger. “Take this to the library. West wing. Do not run. Do not speak. Do not look at anything. Put it on the table and get out. Now.”

My heart hammered against my ribs, a wild bird trapped in a cage of bone. This was it. The chance. My hands trembled as I took the heavy silver tray. It held a simple meal: a small loaf of dark bread, a wedge of goat cheese, a cluster of grapes, and a single clay goblet of wine. It was a meal for a shepherd. The irony was a bitter twist in my gut. I navigated the corridors of the service wing, my bare feet making no sound on the cool stone. I passed through a door and the world changed. The noise and heat of the kitchen vanished, replaced by a sudden, profound silence. The floors were no longer rough stone but polished mosaic, intricate patterns of birds and flowers flowing under my dirty feet. The walls were covered in vibrant frescoes of mythological scenes—gods and heroes in dramas of love and war. The air was cool and scented with cedarwood and beeswax. This was the world that had made him, the gilded cage he had spoken of with such contempt. It was more beautiful and more suffocating than I could have ever imagined. I followed the signs of the west wing, my heart a frantic drumbeat against the oppressive silence. I passed no one. Every soul in the villa was either mourning or serving the mourners. I was a ghost moving through the arteries of a sleeping beast.

I found the door at the end of a long, quiet corridor. It was made of dark, polished wood, inlaid with ivory. It was utterly unassuming and more intimidating than any fortress gate. For a moment, I faltered. My reflection, caught in the polished wood, was a monster. A gaunt, filthy creature with haunted eyes, holding a silver tray meant for a prince. What right did I have to knock on this door? What would he see but the ruin of the boy he had known? I thought of the Sappho scroll, my only clean possession, tucked away in my miserable pallet. I thought of my mother’s face in the darkness, of the months on the road, of the endless, soul-destroying labor. The anger returned, cold and clear. I had not come this far to be defeated by a wooden door. I shifted the tray to one arm, raised my free hand, and knocked. The sound was a desecration in the perfect silence. I waited. Nothing. I knocked again, harder this time. After a long moment, I heard a faint stirring from within, then slow, reluctant footsteps. A bolt scraped back. The door opened.

And he stood there. The Lucius from the Forum, formal and trapped in his dark toga, was gone. This was the Lucius of the hills, or a ghost of him. He wore a simple, undyed tunic, his feet were bare, his hair was uncombed. The room behind him was a chaos of scrolls and books, piled on tables, chairs, and the floor, a fortress built of words. He was gaunter than I remembered, and the storm-grey eyes were clouded with a deep, weary sadness. His gaze fell first to the tray, then rose to my face with an expression of polite, tired dismissal for the servant who had interrupted him. Then his eyes truly saw me. The dismissal vanished, replaced by the same look of raw, incredulous shock I had seen in the Forum. The blood drained from his face, leaving him ashen. His lips parted, but no sound came out. The air between us crackled, the silence of the corridor amplifying the frantic beat of my own heart. He looked past me down the empty hall, his expression turning to one of pure terror, then he seized my arm and pulled me inside, shutting the door behind us with a soft, final click. He leaned back against the wood, his eyes closed for a moment, his chest rising and falling in a ragged rhythm. When he opened his eyes again, they were shining with an unbearable mixture of joy and despair. "Hannelore," he breathed, the name a broken, whispered thing. "What have you done?"## 6.

He repeated the question, his voice a raw whisper, his hand still gripping my arm as if to assure himself I was real, or to keep me from dissolving like a phantom. “Hannelore, what have you done?” His fingers were cold, but a tremor ran through them, a current of frantic energy that passed directly into my own body. He pulled me further into the room, away from the door, his eyes darting back to it as if he expected it to burst open at any second. I could only stand there, mute and overwhelmed, taking in the reality of him. The familiar scent of old parchment and the faint, clean smell of olive soap filled the air, a scent I had thought was lost to me forever. It was the smell of my own soul coming back to me. The tray in my hand trembled, the goblet rattling against the silver with a small, sharp sound that seemed to shatter the silence.

“They will kill you,” Lucius breathed, his voice cracking. He finally let go of my arm, only to grab my shoulders, his grip fierce, almost painful. He shook me slightly, as if to wake me from a dream he thought I was having. “Do you understand me? This is not a story. These are not the shadows on Plato’s cave wall. My uncle, the men who run this house—they are real. They are predators. If they found you, if they knew… knew what you are to me… they would not banish you. They would have you thrown in the Tiber with a stone around your neck, and I would be powerless to stop it. They would call it a tragic accident. A low-born servant, drunk, fell in the river. It happens every day in this city.” His words were a torrent, a desperate flood of the fear he had been living with, and in his storm-grey eyes, I saw not just for myself, but for him.

I set the tray down on a stack of scrolls, the clatter loud in the quiet room. My hands were free. I reached up and covered his hands on my shoulders with my own. My palms were calloused and filthy, his were smooth and pale, the contrast a testament to the worlds that separated us. “I know,” I said, and my voice, when it came, was steady.
